intro: Carduus pycnocephalus var. arabicus, commonly known as the Arabian thistle, is a perennial flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the Middle East and North Africa. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of both ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring gray-green, hairy leaves and spiny, lobed stems. Its flowers are usually purple or pink, and it produces small, oval-shaped seeds that are dispersed by wind. The plant is adapted to harsh environments, with deep roots and a waxy cuticle to reduce water loss.
